channel.title: Bare Metal Cloud Status - Incident History

item.title: [RBX1/RBX2][Dedicated Servers] - Servers migration from RBX1 to RBX2
item.description:
THIS IS A SCHEDULED EVENT Apr 28, 22:00 UTC  -  May 2, 05:00 UTC

Apr 11, 22:52 UTC
Scheduled - As part of our continuous improvement plan, maintenance is scheduled on our Bare metal offer.

This may temporarily affect Availability.

Start time : 28/04/2024 22:00 UTC
End time : 02/05/2024 05:00 UTC
Service impact : Servers being moved from RBX1 to RBX2 might be unavailable for up to 7 hours during the night (22:00 UTC => 05:00 UTC).
Service improvement : As part of our continuous improvement policy of our network infrastructure, we will have to move servers from RBX1 to RBX2 due to the EoL (End of life) of RBX1.

Thank you for your understanding.

item.title: [GLOBAL][Dedicated Servers] - Windows OS language & useSpla API change
item.description:
THIS IS A SCHEDULED EVENT Apr 24, 13:00 - 13:15 UTC

Apr 12, 12:43 UTC
Scheduled - As part of our continuous improvement plan, maintenance is scheduled on our Dedicated Servers offer.

Start time : 24/04/2024 13:00 UTC
End time : 24/04/2024 13:15 UTC
Service impact : No impact expected.
Customers not installing any Windows OSes from API and/or installing Windows OSes from OVHcloud control panel are not affected by this change.
Customers using that API call for installing any windows OSes in a display language other English and/or with useSpla flag set to true are affected by this change and need to update their scripts and applications accordingly.
Service improvement : The following API call with details/useSplaand/or details/language attributes within the payload will definitely stop working: POST /dedicated/server/{serviceName}/install/start

Below you can find an example of payload that will stop working for a win2022-dc OS installation:
```json
{
"details": {
"language": "fr",
"useSpla": true,
},
"templateName": "win2022-dc_64"
}
```

With the previous example, here is the target payload that customer can already use and that will continue to work:
```json
{
"userMetadata": [
{
"key": "language",
"value": "fr-fr"
},
{
"key": "useSpla",
"value": "true"
}
],
"templateName": "win2022-dc_64"
}
```

More details and examples can be found in the Documentation Page

Thank you for your understanding.

item.title: [Global][Dedicated Servers] - APIv6 BringYourOwnImage routes operation
item.description:
THIS IS A SCHEDULED EVENT Apr 23, 08:30 - 08:45 UTC

Mar 6, 15:16 UTC
Update - New start time : 23/04/2024 08:30 UTC
New end time : 23/04/2024 08:45 UTC
Service impact : Some API calls definitely removed.

Mar 6, 10:57 UTC
Update - We will be undergoing scheduled maintenance during this time.

Feb 14, 00:54 UTC
Scheduled - As part of our continuous improvement plan, maintenance is scheduled on our Dedicated Servers offer.

Start time : 19/03/2024 09:30 UTC
End time : 19/03/2024 09:45 UTC
Service impact : Some API calls definitely removed.
Service improvement : As part of our continuous improvement policy of our servers, this maintenance will enables customers to deploy cloudready images directly on their dedicated server.

The following API calls will be definitely removed:

GET /dedicated/server/{serviceName}/bringYourOwnImage

POST /dedicated/server/{serviceName}/bringYourOwnImage

DELETE /dedicated/server/{serviceName}/bringYourOwnImage

Customers can still use the Bring Your Own Image (BYOI) feature from the API call POST /dedicated/server/{serviceName}/install/start. More details can be found in the documentation page.
This change was required in order to add the new Bring Your Own Linux (BYOLinux) feature.
Bring Your Own Image (BYOI) / Bring Your Own Linux (BYOLinux), a comparison sheet - OVHcloud.

item.title: [Worldwide][Dedicated Servers] - IPXE scripts migration
item.description:
THIS IS A SCHEDULED EVENT Apr 16, 08:30 - 08:45 UTC

Apr 15, 10:40 UTC
Update - We will be undergoing scheduled maintenance during this time.

Mar 5, 23:28 UTC
Scheduled - Start time :16/04/2024 08:30 UTC
End time : 16/04/2024 08:45 UTC
Service impact : None
Service improvement : Our iPXE scripts API is evolving, we are simplifying the API call format used to boot a server from a custom iPXE script.
The API calls to make the server boot from the local disk or the rescue are not affected by this change. If you don't know what an iPXE script is, then you are probably not impacted by this change.
The 16th April 2024, we will remove the compatibility with the old method.
Customers can already start using the new method to boot a server from an iPXE script: see the following documentation for more details.

Old method that will stop working
1. The customer adds an iPXE script in their account by using API call POST /me/ipxeScript.
Note that this API call has already been removed the 5th of March 2024: see this status task.
2. For a specific server, the customer calls GET /dedicated/server/{serviceName}/boot?bootType=ipxeCustomerScript to list all compatible iPXE scripts: it returns boot IDs.
3. For any boot ID returned by previous API call, the customer needs to call GET /dedicated/server/{serviceName}/boot/{bootId} to get details untill they find which boot ID corresponds to the previously added iPXE script.
4. Then, the customer needs to call PUT /dedicated/server/{serviceName} with the "bootId" key and the previously obtained boot ID.

New simpler method that is already available
The customer uses the new "bootScript" key within the PUT /dedicated/server/{serviceName} call and directly passes it their iPXE script, see this documentation.
That's it. As you can see it's now less complicated to boot from a custom iPXE script.
